chemical_reaction.description_ru: Chemical transformation that changes the composition of substances. The base process type — all other processes describe conditions, effects, and operations around the reaction.

neutralization.description_ru: Reaction of an acid with a base producing salt and water. Exothermic. Driving force — formation of the weak electrolyte H₂O.

displacement.description_ru: A more active metal displaces a less active one from its salt solution. Governed by the activity series of metals.

heating.description_ru: Raising the system temperature. Increases reaction rate (van't Hoff rule), may shift equilibrium (toward products for endothermic). Modes: water bath, calcination, fusion.

cooling.description_ru: Lowering the system temperature. Reduces reaction rate, shifts equilibrium toward products for exothermic reactions. Used for crystallization and condensation.

stirring.description_ru: Mechanical agitation of the reaction mixture. Increases reagent contact area and mass transfer rate, accelerating heterogeneous reactions.

grinding.description_ru: Reducing the particle size of a solid substance. Increases surface area, accelerating heterogeneous reactions and dissolution.

dilution.description_ru: Adding solvent to a solution. Decreases reagent concentration, reducing reaction rate and potentially shifting equilibrium.

add_excess_reagent.description_ru: Adding one reagent in excess. Shifts equilibrium toward products (Le Chatelier's principle), ensures complete consumption of the limiting reagent.

filtration.description_ru: Separating solid and liquid phases by passing through a filter. The precipitate remains on the filter, the filtrate passes through.

washing.description_ru: Removing impurities from the surface of a precipitate with wash liquid (usually distilled water). Performed after filtration.

drying.description_ru: Removing moisture from a solid substance. Modes: air drying, desiccator, drying oven. Unlike calcination — must not cause chemical decomposition.

evaporation.description_ru: Removing solvent by heating a solution. Used to obtain solid from solution (evaporative crystallization) or to concentrate a solution.

decantation.description_ru: Pouring off liquid from a sediment without filtration. Used when the precipitate is heavy and settles well.

distillation.description_ru: Separating a liquid mixture into fractions by evaporation and condensation. Based on differences in boiling points of components.

dissolution.description_ru: Transfer of a substance into solution on contact with a solvent. Can be exo- or endothermic. Depends on temperature, stirring, and degree of grinding.

crystallization.description_ru: Formation of solid crystals from a supersaturated solution. The reverse of dissolution. Accelerated by cooling or evaporation.

sublimation.description_ru: Transition of a substance from solid to gas bypassing the liquid phase. Classic example — iodine sublimation. Used for purification.

condensation.description_ru: Transition of a substance from gas to liquid upon cooling or pressure increase.

melting.description_ru: Transition of a substance from solid to liquid when heated to the melting point.

boiling.description_ru: Vigorous transition of liquid to gas at the boiling point. Boiling point depends on pressure.

dissociation.description_ru: Breakdown of an electrolyte into ions in solution or melt. Strong electrolytes dissociate completely (α≈1), weak ones partially (α≪1, characterized by K_diss).

precipitation.description_ru: Formation of an insoluble solid (precipitate) from solution. Driving force of ion exchange reactions — product leaves the solution. Characterized by Ksp.

gas_evolution.description_ru: Formation of a gaseous product that leaves the reaction medium. Driving force — product exits the system, shifting equilibrium to the right.

gas_absorption.description_ru: Dissolving a gas in liquid with possible chemical interaction. Example: CO₂ + NaOH → Na₂CO₃. Depends on pressure and temperature.

complexation.description_ru: Formation of a complex ion from a central atom (metal ion) and ligands. Example: Al(OH)₃ + NaOH(excess) → Na[Al(OH)₄]. Characterized by stability constant β.

water_formation.description_ru: Formation of the weak electrolyte H₂O from H⁺ and OH⁻ ions. The main driving force of neutralization and many ion exchange reactions.

weak_electrolyte_formation.description_ru: Formation of a weakly dissociating substance from ions in solution. Generalization of water_formation — includes weak acids (HF, H₂CO₃, H₂S), NH₃·H₂O, etc.

catalysis.description_ru: Changing reaction rate via a catalyst that is not consumed. Lowers activation energy, does not change ΔH or equilibrium position.

adsorption.description_ru: Uptake of a substance from solution or gas onto the surface of a solid (adsorbent). Example: activated carbon removes impurities from water.

photodecomposition.description_ru: Decomposition of a substance by light. Example: AgCl darkens in light (2AgCl → 2Ag + Cl₂). Used as a qualitative test for silver chloride.

electrolysis.description_ru: Redox process at electrodes when direct current passes through an electrolyte solution or melt. Cathode — reduction, anode — oxidation.

remove_gas.description_ru: Formal constraint: gaseous product leaves the system (open vessel, venting). Shifts equilibrium toward gas formation — reaction goes to completion.

remove_solid.description_ru: Formal constraint: precipitate exits the solution (sedimentation or filtration). Reduces product concentration in solution, shifting equilibrium to the right.

closed_system.description_ru: Constraint: the system does not exchange matter with the surroundings. Gases are not removed, equilibrium is established. Important for equilibrium and Le Chatelier's principle problems.

excess_condition.description_ru: Formal constraint: one reagent is present in excess. Determines stoichiometry (limiting reagent is fully consumed) and may affect the product (e.g., CO₂+NaOH with excess/deficit).
